main event: An unidentified flying object was sighted near St. Louis, Missouri on November 1, 1956, by a military source at around 2:25 A.M. The object was described as a round light, the size of an F-94 aircraft, very bright, and traveling at about 3,000 mph at an estimated altitude of 15,000 to 20,000 feet.
interesting points: The object was spotted by a serious-minded and experienced pilot, Captain Daniel, who was initially reluctant to submit the report.
The object was observed to have a steady orange light with a low-level flight path, visible at an altitude of about 23,000 feet, and later reaching an altitude of 33,000 feet.
The object's speed was much greater than the surrounding jet aircraft, and its size and apparent arc were mentioned in the report.
There was no sound heard from the object, and it suddenly disappeared as if it turned off its light.
The pilot turned with the radar to attempt to acquire the object in flight and observed that it definitely was not a meteor.
sighted object: a round light the size of an F-94 aircraft and traveling at about 3,000 mph
witnesses: Captain Daniel, Aerial Weather Reconnaissance Officer
